header.title: The Scroll of Set
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Setianism, Magical Practice, Organizational Management
keywords: Food, Shelter and Medical Care Committee

central_thesis: This issue of The Scroll of Set outlines both practical magical techniques, specifically simultaneous rituals, and the foundational organizational strategies for the Temple of Set, including disaster preparedness via the First Foundation and internal communication systems like 'Operation On Call.' It also delves into the philosophical nature of Set/HarWer and encourages continuous evolution and active participation from its members.

structure_content.summary: This article defines 'simultaneous ritual' as a magical ceremony performed by two or more individuals or groups concurrently in different geographical locations to enhance magical working power and experiment with energy/thought transfer. It details preparation steps including choosing a mutual ritual, personalizing the rite, exchanging photos, determining devices, coordinating exact start times (using phone calls or timed tape recordings with background music), and executing sections simultaneously.

This article introduces the First Foundation (1F), an initiative to plan for the protection of the Temple of Set and its members during catastrophes or societal breakdowns. 1F aims to be open, transparent, and collaborative, with membership for II°+ initiates (or I° with talent). It establishes four committees (Communications, Transportation, Food/Shelter/Medical Care, and Quality of Life) to research and develop multi-level action plans (Levels A-D, from severe global catastrophe to regional disruption) for various disaster scenarios.

This section announces new features in The Scroll, including reports from Temple element directors and a new series on 'practical magic.' It invites contributions from III°+ Initiates and comments/questions from I°/II° members, emphasizing the desire to make practical magic a regular feature. It also clarifies that 'Input' (Scroll #II-8) was an anonymous submission, noting that anonymity is considered for valid reasons but credit is preferred.
A brief announcement of the passing of William C. Bennett I°, born November 2, 1919, and died April 10, XII.

This article discusses the continuous evolution of the Temple of Set and introduces 'Operation On Call' as a system to streamline inquiries regarding Temple policy, philosophy, and magic. It aims to prevent the High Priest, Executive Director, and Scroll Staff from being overwhelmed by correspondence, directing inquiries through ALP/OC to appropriate III°+ Initiates for response, thereby maintaining personal relationships within the evolving structure and allowing key figures to focus on other Temple work.
Announcement of the formation of the Sekhmet Pylon in Santa Barbara, California, with contact information for its Guardian, L. Dale Seago IV°.

A descriptive caption for a photograph of a gold-sheathed statue of the goddess Selket, noted as a guardian of Tutankhamen's burial chamber, displayed in Chicago's Field Museum, with a scorpion headpiece.

This article explores the nature and 'sex' of Set/HarWer, addressing the difficulty new Setians face in understanding these concepts, often influenced by Christian teachings. It defines Set as 'ageless Intelligence' and HarWer as Set's 'Opposite Self,' a 'strange and fitful presence.' Using wind as a symbolic analogy (Set as a gentle breeze, HarWer as a hurricane), the author argues against assigning gender or limited form to these entities, advocating for personal symbolic understanding that does not confine their true nature.

structure_content.chapter_title: From the Rite of Bubastis Pylon
structure_content.summary: A ceremonial text or invocation in honor of the Festival of Bubastis. It includes hails to Bast, Lady of the Pylon, invoking her joyous and peaceful presence for life, strength, health, and joy, and hails to Sekhmet, Lady of the Pylon, invoking her fierce, protective presence against enmity and discord.

key_concepts.definition: A magical ceremony performed by two or more individuals or groups at the same time in different geographical locations, intended to strengthen magical workings and experiment with magical energy exchange or thought transfer.

An organizational initiative within the Temple of Set tasked with preparing plans to protect the Temple and its members during major catastrophes or societal breakdowns, structured into four committees covering communications, transportation, food/shelter/medical care, and quality of life.

The occult organization itself, undergoing evolution and seeking to establish robust internal systems for communication, member support, and disaster preparedness, while fostering individual magical and philosophical growth (Xeper).
A core Setian principle implicitly understood as a path of self-evolution and becoming, referenced in the context of the Temple's growth and individual advancement.

A dualistic principle within Setian cosmology, where Set is 'the ageless Intelligence of this Universe' and HarWer is Set's 'Opposite Self,' described as a 'strange and fitful presence.' They are presented as non-gendered entities, best understood symbolically rather than confined to specific forms.

An internal system designed to handle inquiries from Temple members regarding policy, philosophy, and magic by directing them through ALP/OC to the most appropriate III°+ Initiate, thereby streamlining communication and reducing administrative burden on leadership.
A local organizational unit or lodge within the Temple of Set, serving as a hub for activities and member interaction (e.g., Sekhmet Pylon, Bubastis Pylon).

A term used to describe the exploration of phenomena related to energy transfer, development of magical strength, and application of magical techniques in daily and ceremonial life, distinct from purely theoretical or philosophical magic.

practical_system.description: The document presents a system for advanced magical practice through 'Simultaneous Rituals' and a comprehensive framework for organizational resilience and communication within the Temple of Set. It emphasizes coordinated magical efforts across distances and a multi-tiered approach to disaster preparedness and internal support. The 'On Call' system provides a structured method for inquiries, ensuring efficient communication within the hierarchy.
tools: Pictures of participants and their ritual chambers
Timed tape recordings (for synchronizing ritual sections)
rituals: Simultaneous Rituals (preparation includes mutual interest/benefit, shared ritual text, exchange of personal/chamber photos, determining devices, exact time coordination via phone or timed recordings)
Rite of Bubastis Pylon (invocation to Bast and Sekhmet for protection and blessings)

relevant_quotes.text: A rough definition of “simultaneous ritual" is: a magical ceremony performed by two or more individuals or groups at the same time in different geographical locations.
The time has come to begin anew the task of preparing for the possibility that a plan is required to protect the Temple of Set and its members in the event of a catastrophe or societal breakdown.
I am the ageless Intelligence of this Universe.
But HarWer, my Opposite Self, is a strange and fitful presence.
Change through evolution is as inevitable as it is necessary if we are to accomplish healthy evolution.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue is highly relevant for understanding the formative years of the Temple of Set (1977), showcasing its early practical magical interests (simultaneous rituals), its proactive approach to organizational resilience and member welfare during potential societal disruptions (First Foundation), and its internal communication structures ('Operation On Call'). It provides insight into the practical implementation of Setian philosophy, the ongoing evolution of the organization, and the development of its internal cosmology regarding Set/HarWer. It's a snapshot of a vibrant, growing occult organization addressing both esoteric theory and real-world practicalities for its members.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Primarily members and initiates of the Temple of Set (especially II° and III°+ Initiates) interested in practical magic, organizational development, and Setian philosophy. Secondary audiences include scholars of modern Western Esotericism, particularly those studying the history and practices of the Temple of Set and similar Left Hand Path organizations.
